author: Amy Kuperinsky | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: 12 New Jersey fall adventures for 2015
text:
Comments 
Editor's note: This post was written prior to reports of Hurricane Joaquin impacting the region. As of publication time, all of these events are still scheduled to go on, but please check NJ.com regularly for updates. 
New Jersey is beautiful at many times of the year — gleaming in the Shore sunshine, placid in the winter frost — but fall in the Garden State has its own crisp, crunchy charms. 
Here are some ways to enjoy the autumn season in the form of a fall adventure, whether that means foliage-seeking excursions, Halloween frights or paeans to the pumpkin. The outings listed below span 13 of the state's 21 counties, and each is doable as a day trip — though some will require a longer drive than others. 
In the comments below, please tell us what other fall experiences you enjoy. High Point State Park . If this isn't the definition of picturesque, it's got to be close. What better place to survey the turning of the leaves than the highest point in the state? Ascend to the High Point Monument in Sussex, at 1,803 feet above sea level, and get a bird's eye view of the colors of fall near Lake Marcia. See the highest point in the state at High Point State Park in Sussex. Also pictured: Lake Marcia and the 220-foot High Point Monument. (New Jersey DEP Division of Parks and Forestry) 
Lighthouse Challenge of New Jersey . Maybe you'd like a seascape with your foliage? The Lighthouse Challenge is no timed race, but rather a self-guided tour of the state's oceanside beacons over two days, from Oct. 17 to 18. Included in the jaunt are the Barnegat, Cape May and Sea Girt lighthouses, as well as Sandy Hook Light, the oldest standing lighthouse in the country. Visit lhchallengenj.org for a full list of participating lighthouses. Zombie walks . Though its original organizer had announced its demise in August, the New Jersey Zombie Walk in Asbury Park has been reanimated and is raring to lurch forward as planned on Oct. 3 in Asbury Park . The event runs from noon to 8 p.m.; meet on the boardwalk at 4 p.m. for the parade of the undead. Boonton gets in on the ghoulish fun as it hosts its first 'Booonton' Zombie Walk along Main Street from 5 to 9 p.m. on Oct. 2; visit boontonmainstreet.org . The Smithville Zombie Walk , another celebrated zombie procession in Atlantic County, descends upon Galloway Township from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. (walk starts at 6) on Halloween ( Oct. 31 ; rain date Nov. 1). RELATED: New Jersey Zombie Walk lives again: 5 things to know Jax corn maze . She made it farther than any New Jerseyan on "American Idol." Now the East Brunswick singer Jax has her own corn maze. VonThun Farms in Monmouth Junction, which dedicated its corn maze to Derek Jeter last year, has a Jax tribute for fall 2015. Navigating the nooks and crannies of the farm labyrinth takes just 20 minutes to complete, but most figure it out within an hour; visit vonthunfarms.com A scene from the 2011 New Jersey Zombie Walk in Asbury Park. The event, initially canceled for this year, has been brought back from the dead. (Saed Hindash/The Star-Ledger) The South Jersey Pumpkin Show . There would be hard to find a more pumpkin-centric event. The South Jersey Pumpkin Show, which runs Oct. 9 through 11 at the Salem County Fairgrounds in Woodstown, has a pumpkin pyramid, pumpkin weigh-off, pumpkin food contest, Little Miss and Mister Pumpkin pageant and a lot more orange squash-oriented entertainment; visit sjpumpkinshow.com RELATED: 79 N.J. fall festivals for 2015 Pumpkin launching . Need to get out some fall frustration? Send a pumpkin flying into the air or shoot corn out of a cannon at — perhaps ironically — Tranquillity Farms in Allamuchy. It's $1 a shot for pumpkins, or six for $5 and five shots for $3 for the corn. Visit tranquillityfarmsnj.com Batsto Village . What says fall more than Pine Barrens history? Tour the grounds of the historical site of an ironworking and glass-making community nestled in the Pine Barrens' Wharton State Forest, the largest piece of land in the state park system. On Oct. 18 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., there's a Country Living Fair at the village. On Oct. 24 from 4:30 to 6:30 p.m., there's a "Jersey Devil Bound" event with ghost stories and a twilight hike. On Oct. 25 from noon to 3 p.m., children 12 and younger and their parents are invited to a "haunting the pines" event. Visit batstovillage.org An aerial view of the the corn maze at VonThun Farms in Monmouth Junction. This year the maze is dedicated to Jax, an 'American Idol' finalist from East Brunswick. (VonThun Farms) (Haunted) Tuckerton Seaport . In Ocean County, Tuckerton Creek's landmark will be decked out for the season of spirits with ghost pirates and ship captains, hayrides, the Jersey Devil, the Black Pearl Pirate Ship and glow-in-the-dark mini-golf. The festivities run from Oct. 24 through 26, from 6 to 9 p.m. Visit tuckertonseaport.org Washington Crossing State Park . It was here where Gen. George Washington crossed the Delaware River, but you can take in the foliage. The backdrop looks like it's made for autumn landscape photos. If you are so moved, you can head from Hopewell Township over to the Washington Crossing Historic Park on the Pennsylvania side, where park staff are asking visitors to enter a "Capture the Park" photo contest with any picture that "captures the essence of autumn." At dusk on Oct. 23, visitors to the historic park can catch the park's "Films at the Farmstead" series of outdoor movie screenings at the Thompson-Neely House in Solebury Township, Pa., featuring the seasonally appropriate "Maleficent." Burt and Hollis Cohen of Yardley, Pa. go for a fall walk in Hopewell Township near Washington Crossing State Park in 2006. (Frank Jacobs III/The Times of Trenton) Take a tour of 'Friday the 13th . ' The iconic 1980 horror film was shot in New Jersey's northwest, and while the real "Camp Crystal Lake," — Camp No-Be-Bo-Sco, a boy scout camp in Hardwick Township — is not open to the public, there are other places seen in the film that are, including the Blairstown Diner , downtown Blairstown , and Millbrook Road; visit fridaythe13thfilms.com/bts/locations/part1.html Fall at Howell Farm . For many, fall means farms, and Mercer County's Howell Living History Farm recreates farm conditions that existed in 1900. The farm has hayrides (Oct. 17), a corn maze (open weekends in October and through Nov. 1), pumpkin carving (Oct. 9 through 11), but also a Harvest Moon Barn Dance (Nov. 6) and cider-making (Nov. 7). Closed Mondays. Visit howellfarm.org Frightful tales at the Great Swamp . Chatham Township's Great Swamp Outdoor Education Center invites families to Trail Tales, an outdoor Halloween storytelling adventure on Oct. 24. Storytellers in costume will relay the tales against the backdrop of glowing jack-o'-lanterns. Rain or shine; for ages 4 and up. To register for a slot between 5:30 and 7:45 p.m., call (973) 635-6629. For more, visit morrisparks.net/calendars.asp Amy Kuperinsky may be reached at akuperinsky@njadvancemedia.com . Follow her on Twitter @AmyKup . Find NJ.com Entertainment on Facebook .
